conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph to determine acceleration phases and calculate the ratio of accelerations.

The image shows a velocity-time graph for particles A and B, both starting from rest at t = 0. Particle A has a constant acceleration phase from t = 0 to t = 3, followed by deceleration. Particle B shows constant acceleration throughout.
Identify acceleration phases for particles A and B where velocity increases linearly with time.
For particle A, acceleration phase is from t = 0 to t = 3 with linear velocity increase, indicating constant acceleration.
For particle B, the entire graph shows linear velocity increase, indicating constant acceleration from t = 0 to t = 6.
Calculate acceleration using the slope of the velocity-time graph: a = Δv/Δt.
For particle A, the slope is 2/3, giving an acceleration of a_A = 2/3.
For particle B, the slope is 2/6, giving an acceleration of a_B = 1/3.
Determine the ratio of their accelerations: a_A/a_B = (2/3)/(1/3) = 2.
